title: What is the first thing that EMTs or paramedics would want to know about the patient as they first arrive on scene? - Quora

response.answer_text: The protocol is almost universal: Scene Safety - initiate standard precautions.Scene Size UpNumber of patientsMechanism of injury / Nature of IllnessEquipment & resources needed (likely — initial impression).3. Airway - Breathing - Circulation Make any necessary interventions. 4. Level of Response (Alert - Voice - Pain - Unresponsive) 5. Primary survey - chief complaint — relay to EMS 6. Secondary survey — look for any other injuries/problems Take initial set of vitals. That’s more than “the first thing”, but really you have to complete all of these as the first on scene, so I can’t pick one single thing.

What is the first thing that EMTs or paramedics would want to know about the patient as they first arrive on scene? “BSI, scene safety.” Okay, now that that’s out of the way, the first thing I need to know is whether the patient is responsive or not. It’s the BLS algorithm. The first thing I actually need to know in general is whether or not it is safe for my crew and me to actually be at the scene. The first thing I need to know about my patient is their level of consciousness.

The answer to whatever question we ask first. And we do want to hear it from the patient to assess a lot of things like their level of consciousness, ability and work of breathing, and level of impairment from any drugs or alcohol they may have taken. If we have any difficulty, or have additional questions the patient can't answer, then we'll turn to bystanders. Unless you have information relating to our safety, or background we really need to know, let us talk to the patient first…

Does he have insurance or major credit card? Juuuuuuust kidding. ABCs. A - does the patient have a patent and open airway? Does fixing it solve the problem? B - is the patient breathing? Yes. Is it adequate or inadequate? No breathing or inadequate, breathe for them. C - circulation Does the patient have a radial or carotid pulse? No, begin CPR. M - what is the mental status? Transport priority is made on those 4.

After ensuring that the scene is safe and we are wearing appropriate PPE, I want to know if the patient is breathing, conscious, and where they are located in the building/house. This way we can direct someone to get the proper moving device out of the ambulance as I make my way inside to see the patient.
Past Medical History is one of my initial questions and the answer can tell you a lot about why we have been called and what may be going on with the patient presently
Why did they call for an ambulance. What is the Chief Complaint?
